findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The transactions are initially disabled for all users excluding the authorized addresses. The owner can enable the transactions for all users. Once the transactions are enabled the owner will not be able to disable them again.

findings.title: BC - Blacklists Addresses
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop contract addresses from transactions.

findings.title: ZD - Zero Division
findings.description: The contract is using variables that may be set to zero as denominators, leading to unpredictable and potentially harmful results.

findings.title: PAV - Pair Address Validation
findings.description: The contract lacks address validation in the pair address argument, which can lead to security risks and potential attacks.

findings.title: RVD - Redundant Variable Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares certain variables that are not used in a meaningful way by the contract. As a result, these variables are redundant.

findings.title: OCTD - Transfers Contract's Tokens
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to claim all the balance of the contract by calling the `rescueToken` function.

findings.title: ULTW - Transfers Liquidity to Team Wallet
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to transfer funds without limit to the team wallet.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `utilityReceiver` and `buybackReceiver` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of certain variables even when their current state matches the provided argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure that their values cannot be changed after they have been set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide provides guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code, improving readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: Boolean equality is unnecessary when comparing two boolean values.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.
